skill.name: naming-analyzer
skill.description: Suggest better variable, function, and class names based on context and conventions.
skill.summary: Suggest better variable, function, and class names based on context and conventions.
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill with no code execution, file system access, or network capabilities. It provides naming convention analysis and suggestions based on the code context provided by the user.

content.user_title: Analyze and fix poor naming in your code
content.value_statement: Bad naming makes code hard to understand and maintain. This skill analyzes your code and suggests clearer, more descriptive names following language conventions.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes variables, functions, classes, and constants for naming issues
Detects vague, misleading, or abbreviated names
Suggests better alternatives with clear reasoning
Identifies boolean naming violations and magic numbers
Provides refactoring priorities and migration scripts
limitations: Requires code context to provide accurate suggestions
Cannot automatically rename variables in your codebase
Limited to analyzing provided code snippets or files

use_cases.title: Learn proper naming conventions
use_cases.description: Get instant feedback on variable and function names to build good habits early in your coding journey.

use_cases.title: Standardize naming across teams
use_cases.description: Ensure consistent naming patterns across your team's codebase during code reviews.

use_cases.title: Refactor confusing legacy names
use_cases.description: Identify and prioritize renaming efforts in old codebases with unclear or outdated naming.

prompt_templates.title: Quick name check
prompt_templates.scenario: Review a single function or variable name
prompt_templates.prompt: @naming-analyzer Is 'processData(data)' a good function name? It validates and transforms user input.

prompt_templates.title: File analysis
prompt_templates.scenario: Analyze naming in an entire file
prompt_templates.prompt: @naming-analyzer Review the naming in src/utils/helpers.js and suggest improvements

prompt_templates.title: Convention check
prompt_templates.prompt: @naming-analyzer --conventions Are these Python names following PEP 8? user_name, getUserData, is_valid_email

prompt_templates.title: Full refactor
prompt_templates.prompt: @naming-analyzer --fix-all Suggest better names for: usr, tmp, proc, data, val, arr in my codebase

output_examples.input: Check if 'getUserInfo' is a good function name that fetches and updates user data
output: ‚ùå Issue: Function name implies read-only operation but has side effects
üîç Current: getUserInfo() - fetches user and updates lastLogin
üí° Reason: Name should reflect that it modifies data, not just retrieves it

best_practices: Use descriptive names that reveal intent without needing comments
Follow language conventions consistently (camelCase, snake_case, PascalCase)
Make boolean names obvious with is/has/can/should prefixes
Avoid abbreviations except for well-known terms like HTML, API, URL
anti_patterns: Single-letter variables outside of loop counters
Generic names like data, info, temp that don't convey meaning
Mixing naming conventions within the same project

faq.question: Which programming languages does it support?
faq.answer: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Java, Go, and general principles apply to most languages.

faq.question: How does it detect misleading names?
faq.answer: It analyzes if the name accurately describes what the code actually does, including side effects.

faq.question: Can it automatically rename my variables?
faq.answer: No, it provides suggestions and can generate refactoring scripts, but you apply changes manually.

faq.question: Is my code sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No, analysis happens locally within your AI tool - no code leaves your machine.

faq.question: What if my team has different naming conventions?
faq.answer: Use the suggestions as a guide and adapt them to your team's specific standards.

faq.question: How does it compare to IDE refactoring tools?
faq.answer: It provides intelligent naming suggestions with explanations, while IDEs mainly automate safe renaming.
